Prompt:
Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 200 words. Here's a possible topic: "How Computers Talk to Each Other"

Computers talk to each other like friends talk to each other. They use words called codes. These codes are secret. Only the computers understand them. Sometimes, a bad guy wants to listen. The bad guy wants to know the secret codes. But the computers are smart. They use special codes to keep the bad guy away. These special codes are called encryption. Computers use encryption to keep their talks safe. It's like they have a secret language. Only good computers can understand it. So, the bad guy can't listen. The computers stay safe.

In this paragraph, include the following information: a computer is vulnerable to hackers, hackers try to get into computers without permission, passwords protect computers, but weak passwords can be easily broken, strong passwords are harder to guess, and using different passwords for each account helps keep computers safe.

A computer is like a house. It stores important things, like games, photos, and secrets. But a computer can be vulnerable, like a house with an open door. Hackers are like sneaky burglars. They try to get into computers without permission. They want to steal things or cause trouble. But computers have locks, like passwords. Passwords protect computers, just like locks protect houses. But some passwords are weak, like easy-to-guess locks. A hacker can break a weak password quickly. So, it's important to use strong passwords. But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 200 words. In this paragraph, explain the importance of keeping a computer password secret.

Computers are like houses for our important things. These things could be our school work, games, or even pictures of our family. But sometimes, not-so-nice people want to get into these houses without permission. They might want to look at our stuff or even change it. This is why we need a secret code to keep our computers safe. This secret code is called a password. We should never tell anyone else our password, not even our best friend. If someone else knows our password, they could get into our computer and cause trouble. So, it's very important to keep our password a secret, just like we would hide our toys so our little brother can't play with them. This way, only we can get into our computer and keep our things safe.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 200 words. Here's a hint: Use the word 'hackers' and describe how they try to 'break into' computers.

In the digital world, there are 'hackers'. They try to break into computers. They want to find secrets or cause trouble. They use tricks and tools to get into computers. These tricks are like keys that try to open locked doors. But computers have strong locks. These locks are called'security software'. They protect computers from hackers. Some computers have many locks. These computers are very safe. Other computers have fewer locks. They might not be as safe. It's important to have strong locks on your computer. This helps keep hackers out. It helps protect your secrets. It helps keep your computer safe.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 200 words. Here's a possible answer:

A computer is like a secret clubhouse. You want only your friends to come inside. So, you lock the door. But you need a special password to unlock it. This password is like a secret knock. It's different for every person. If someone tries to guess your password, they can't come in. That's how computer security works. It keeps bad guys out. They can't see your special things, like your games or your pictures. So, always use a strong password. Don't tell it to anyone. That way, only you can unlock your clubhouse.
